Linux/Arch-Linux-Installation-guide.title: Arch Linux Installation guide
Linux/Arch-Linux-Installation-guide.content:
Into Â§
This is a very high level summary guide on installing Arch linux. This is not step by step tutorial for beginner.
Prerequisite Â§

Secure Boot Disabled
Check if your system is UEFI or BOIS
Burn the Arch linux iso on a usb device

Installation Â§
Reboot the machine pick usb device in bootloader and proceed to following.
Keymaps Â§
Keymap are highly individual specific depending on the keyboard one would use. RTFM.
Internet Â§
Internet connection is necessary to make successful install pick wired connection or wireless
Wired Connection Â§
If the machine has physical wire connection this step is done.
Run ping www.google.com
If network timeout or any indication of failed network connectivity - RTFM.
Wireless Connection Â§
To get interactive wifi connection prompt, do iwctl
help
device list , display a list of devices capable to do wireless connections.
station wlan1 scan Note, (wlan1) is not constant it may or may not be different for machine to machine.
station wlan1 get-networks Display previously scan wifi(s) access points.
station wlan connect "my wifi" Connect to the wifi, if oneâ€™s wifi has wpa2 enable , iwctl will as passphrase, act accordingly.
Once the machine is sure of internet connectivity, do timedatectl set-ntp true.
Mirrors Â§
Optimize the mirrors according to machineâ€™s physical location.
Install mirror configuration tool Â§
pacman -Sy reflector
Configure mirrors with Reflector Â§
Make a list of country thatâ€™s closet to the machineâ€™s physical location.
reflector -c "Switzerland","United State" --latest 6 --protocol https --sort rate --save /etc/pacman.d/mirrorlist

pacman -Syyy
Partitioning Â§
Check the partitions with lsblk
Apply partition with cfdisk
Format the partition for primary filesystem (ext4) mkfs.ext4 /dev/sda1
Format the partition for swap mkswap /dev/sda2 swapon /dev/sda2
Mounting Â§
Mount the filesystem with mount /dev/sda1 /mnt
Create dir to mount boot mkdir /mnt/boot
Mount the boot partition with mount /dev/sda3 /mnt/boot
Base install Â§
pacstrap /mnt base linux linux-headers linux-firmware vim
FSTAB Â§
Generate FSTAB - genfstab -U /mnt >> /mnt/etc/fstab
Check it /mnt/etc/fstab
Chroot Â§
arch-chroot /mnt
Locales Â§


Search your timezone
timedatectl list-timezones | grep Yangon



Apply timezone
ln -sf /usr/share/zoneinfo/Asia/Yangon /etc/localtime

hwclock --systohc



Apply locale
vim /etc/locale.gen

locale-gen

echo "LANG=en_US.UTF-8" >> /etc/locale.conf



Hostname Â§
vim /etc/hostname
Arch

vim /etc/hosts
127.0.0.1   localhost
::1         localhost
127.0.1.1   arch.localdomain    arch

Set Root password Â§
Do passwd as root user
GRUB Â§

Install necessary packages

    pacman -Sy grub efibootmgr os-prober ntfs-3g networkmanager network-manager-applet wireless_tools wpa_supplicant dialog mtools osfstools base-devel git bluez bluez-utils openssh

Install Grub (EFI)
grub-install --target=x86_64-efi --efi-directory=/boot --bootloader-id=Arch


Grub config
grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg



Enable system services Â§

Network - systemctl enable NetworkManager
Bluetooth - systemctl enable bluetooth
SSH - systemctl enable sshd

New User Â§

Add user  useradd -mG wheel kmt passwd kmt
Make wheel group sudo EDITOR=vim visudo and uncomment %wheel ALL=(ALL) ALL

Finish Installation Â§

exit chroot exit
unmount umount -a
reboot reboot

Mathematics/Understanding-the-fundamenta.title: Understanding the fundamentals of summation symbol (sigma) in mathematic
Mathematics/Understanding-the-fundamenta.content:
Summation Symbol (âˆ‘) Â§
In mathematic the summation symbol capital sigma is generally used to reqpresents summation of similar terms.
Simple Sum Â§
For example, adding a sequence of number up to the n number starting from 1 can be compactly describe in this manner:
i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹i=1+2+3+...+nwhere,iÂ =Â lowerboundÂ ofÂ theÂ summationnÂ =Â upperboundÂ ofÂ theÂ summationâ€‹
More generally, the expression âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹xiâ€‹ represents the sum of n terms
x1â€‹+x2â€‹+x3â€‹+...+xnâ€‹
A few more examples:
i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹4xiâ€‹â€‹=4x1â€‹+4x2â€‹+4x3â€‹+...+4xnâ€‹=4(x1â€‹+x2â€‹+x3â€‹+...+xnâ€‹)â€‹
Thus,
i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹4xiâ€‹=4(i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xiâ€‹)
Another example:
i=1âˆ‘3â€‹(xiâ€‹+yiâ€‹)â€‹=(x1â€‹+y1â€‹)+(x2â€‹+y2â€‹)+(x3â€‹+y3â€‹)=x1â€‹+x2â€‹+x3â€‹+y1â€‹+y2â€‹+y3â€‹â€‹
Thus,
i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹(xiâ€‹+yiâ€‹)=i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xiâ€‹+i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹yiâ€‹
Attention Â§
We must not confuse the following expressions pairs. Because the expression:
i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xiâ€‹yiâ€‹
is not the same as:
(i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xiâ€‹)(i1â€‹âˆ‘nâ€‹yiâ€‹)
And the expression
i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xi2â€‹
is not the same as:
(i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xiâ€‹)2
Letâ€™s explorer further on why that is by subsituting some arbitrary numbers into the variables.
For example, given i=1, n=3, x1â€‹=4, x2â€‹=2, x3â€‹=7 and y1â€‹=2, y2â€‹=2, y3â€‹=3:
Conclusion 1,
i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xiâ€‹yiâ€‹x1â€‹y1â€‹+x2â€‹y2â€‹+x3â€‹y3â€‹(4âˆ—2)+(2âˆ—2)+(7âˆ—3)31â€‹î€ =(i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xiâ€‹)(i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹yiâ€‹)î€ =(x1â€‹+x2â€‹+x3â€‹)(y1â€‹+y2â€‹+y3â€‹)î€ =(4+2+7)âˆ—(2+2+3)î€ =91â€‹
Conclusion 2,
i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xi2â€‹x12â€‹+x22â€‹+x32â€‹42+22+7269â€‹î€ =(i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xiâ€‹)2î€ =(x1â€‹+x2â€‹+x3â€‹)2î€ =(4+2+7)2î€ =169â€‹
Double Sums Â§
Summation doubles are just simply summation of a summation, the below expression are the ones youâ€™ll likely encounter when youâ€™re dealing with double sums.
The basic double sum expression:
i=1âˆ‘mâ€‹xiâ€‹j=1âˆ‘nâ€‹yjâ€‹â€‹=i=1âˆ‘mâ€‹j=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xiâ€‹yjâ€‹â€‹
Letâ€™s replace some arbitrary numbers into upperbounds of the summations to explore them:
i=1âˆ‘3â€‹j=1âˆ‘2â€‹xiâ€‹yjâ€‹â€‹=i=1âˆ‘3â€‹(xiâ€‹y1â€‹+xiâ€‹y2â€‹)=x1â€‹y1â€‹+x1â€‹y2â€‹+x2â€‹y1â€‹+x2â€‹y2â€‹+x3â€‹y1â€‹+x3â€‹y2â€‹â€‹
Less general case:
(i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xiâ€‹)2â€‹=i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xiâ€‹j=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xjâ€‹=i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹j=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xiâ€‹xjâ€‹=i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xi2â€‹+i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹j=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xiâ€‹xjâ€‹(jî€ =i)â€‹
Explanations for above relations with an example of n=3:
Letâ€™s sort out the  (âˆ‘i=13â€‹xiâ€‹)2 first:
(i=1âˆ‘3â€‹xiâ€‹)2â€‹=(x1â€‹+x2â€‹+x3â€‹)2=(x12â€‹+x22â€‹+x32â€‹)+(2x1â€‹x2â€‹+2x1â€‹x3â€‹+2x2â€‹x3â€‹)=x12â€‹+x22â€‹+x32â€‹+x1â€‹x2â€‹+x1â€‹x3â€‹+x2â€‹x3â€‹+x1â€‹x2â€‹+x1â€‹x3â€‹+x2â€‹x3â€‹â€‹
Exploring relation 1:
i=1âˆ‘3â€‹xiâ€‹j=1âˆ‘3â€‹xjâ€‹â€‹=(x1â€‹+x2â€‹+x3â€‹)(x1â€‹+x2â€‹+x3â€‹)=x12â€‹+x22â€‹+x32â€‹+x1â€‹x2â€‹+x1â€‹x3â€‹+x2â€‹x3â€‹+x1â€‹x2â€‹+x1â€‹x3â€‹+x2â€‹x3â€‹â€‹
Exploring relation 2:
i=1âˆ‘3â€‹j=1âˆ‘3â€‹xiâ€‹xjâ€‹â€‹=i=1âˆ‘3â€‹(xiâ€‹x1â€‹+xiâ€‹x2â€‹+xiâ€‹x3â€‹)=(x1â€‹x1â€‹+x1â€‹x2â€‹+x1â€‹x3â€‹)+(x2â€‹x1â€‹+x2â€‹x2â€‹+x2â€‹x3â€‹)+(x3â€‹x1â€‹+x3â€‹x2â€‹+x3â€‹x3â€‹)=x12â€‹+x22â€‹+x32â€‹+x1â€‹x2â€‹+x1â€‹x3â€‹+x2â€‹x3â€‹+x1â€‹x2â€‹+x1â€‹x3â€‹+x2â€‹x3â€‹â€‹
Explanation for last relation:
i=1âˆ‘3â€‹xi2â€‹+i=1âˆ‘3â€‹j=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xiâ€‹xjâ€‹(iî€ =j)â€‹=(x12â€‹+x22â€‹+x32â€‹)+x1â€‹(x2â€‹+x3â€‹)+x2â€‹(x1â€‹+x3â€‹)+x3â€‹(x1â€‹+x2â€‹)=x12â€‹+x22â€‹+x32â€‹+x1â€‹x2â€‹+x1â€‹x3â€‹+x2â€‹x3â€‹+x1â€‹x2â€‹+x1â€‹x3â€‹+x2â€‹x3â€‹â€‹
There are few other complex double sums examples but weâ€™ll not dive into them in this article.
Double Index Â§
Sometime in computer science and afew other areas where we need to represent the data of a table or a matrix. In the following example weâ€™ll explorer double index notations where in xiâ€‹j the first index (i) represent the number of the row where the data is located and the second (j) to the column.

Given

To figure out the sum of the terms of a row, we fix the index of the row and vary for all possible values, the index of the column.
For exmaple:
j=1âˆ‘3â€‹x1jâ€‹=x11â€‹+x12â€‹+x13â€‹+x14â€‹=2+4+5+1=12

Mind/Avoiding-Sunk-Cost-Fallacy.title: Avoiding Sunk Cost Fallacy
Mind/Avoiding-Sunk-Cost-Fallacy.content:
Whatâ€™s sunk cost anyway? Â§
Sunk cost is the cost the has been put in motioned which cannot be recovered. For example, in practice this can mean money thatâ€™s has been used to purchase machinery in a manufacturing line or past effort and time that has been put towards a goal.
Whatâ€™s sunk cost fallacy Â§
The sunk cost fallacy is a mindset when working through a decision. This fallacy is based on the premise that committing to the current plan is justified because resources have already been committed. This mistake may result in improper long-term strategic planning decisions based on short-term committed costs. In addition this cloud our ability to form new ideas from fresh perspective.

Mind/Famine,-Affluence-And-Morality.title: Famine, Affluence And Morality
Mind/Famine,-Affluence-And-Morality.content:
There are things we have to do and other optional. In other words
obligatory things vs supererogatory
Obligatory vs supererogatory Â§
Imagine youâ€™re have a meeting. Youâ€™re in the meeting room earlier than everyone. You felt thirsty, so you drink up from a bottle you have, but you think to yourself what if everyone else is thirsty. You have idea, itâ€™ll be nice you would placed bottle at the each person place, you got time, meeting wonâ€™t start in 15min. You went back and got all the bottle from company kitchen and placed on there.
You donâ€™t have to do it, but itâ€™s a nice thing to do. but if you were an assigned person to this sort of things done than itâ€™s in your obligation to do it.
Now that I hope you have clear idea of the two words letâ€™s move on.
Is it obligatory to help in relief efforts? Â§
Most of use would think donating money and help in famine or refugee instead of spending money on less moral significant thing such as buying new cars and new phone when the old one work perfectly fine. We donâ€™t have to donate to help but itâ€™s nice if we do, Right?. Well, singer says, no it is a duty to donate and help in those relief, itâ€™s immoral to be otherwise.
Famine, Affluence and Morality Â§
In Famine, Affluence and morality paper by Peter Singer in 1971 the statement was -

If it is in our power to prevent something bad from happening, without thereby sacrificing anything of moral significance, then we ought, morally, to do it.

â€œSomething badâ€ meaning hunger, death, disaster, murder, bad suffering and so on. â€œMorally insignificant thingsâ€ are such as buying a luxury cars which we donâ€™t really need to survive or morally make no difference. Or the abundance of jewelry we buy, phones, video games, nice headphones.
Save a drowning child Â§
Imagine, youâ€™re on your way to work, a very important event at work today, but you see a child drowning in lake on the way, Well?, despite risking being late and getting your suit messed up, most of us would no doubt help the child.
A child drowning is a very bad thing and risk getting messed up our suit and being a little is not of moral significant. Beautifully supporting the philosophy.
Obligatory to donate Â§
This mean it is obligatory to donate in famine relief organization to help people in whatever terrible place it is right now by sacrificing not buying new shiny shoes when our current shoes work perfectly, not buying next iPhones and cars. Itâ€™s immoral otherwise.
Objection by proximity Â§
Wait donating to famine relief isnâ€™t the same thing a drowning child in front of my eyes.
Well, if youâ€™re living medieval age that would be justifiable argument, but today age and days technologies connect the whole world and not being able to help due to distance is no longer an excuse.
This does not invalidate singer point as well.
Objection by Peers Â§
Youâ€™d think other people are donating the charities it wouldnâ€™t be the end of the world for me to not donate and buy new clothes?.
Well, how do you think if I say â€œThere were other people nearby, so I didnâ€™t save the drowning childâ€ or â€œOr I was waiting for other people nearby to recuse the child so just passed byâ€. Singer says the responsibility falls to the individual and itâ€™s not an moral excuse to whether if other people available to help.
This does not invalidate singer point as well.
Conclusion Â§
Singerâ€™s argument is general in scope and not limited to the famine relief or any particular disaster at hands. Itâ€™s as controversial as it sound itâ€™s as radical.
Then weâ€™re all evils? Â§
Are we all evil to spending most of our income on ourselves and luxury?

â€œIf it is in our power to prevent something bad from happening, without thereby sacrificing anything of moral significance, then we ought, morally, to do it.â€ - Peter Singer

Mind/Success-And-Money---The-Behavioural.title: Success And Money - The Behavioural Side of Things
Mind/Success-And-Money---The-Behavioural.content:
These are key-points discussed from the book â€œPsychology of moneyâ€ by Morgan Housel.
The impact of luck and risk Â§
Some religion describe luck as a positive destiny that was brought upon by past lifeâ€™s do goods. And bad luck is a form of punishment for wrong doings in the past life.
But a more general definition of luck I think we could all agree is that outcomes and consequences you cannot control or foresee whatsoever are just happen to be in your favor. Bad luck is the otherwise.
While personal actions and decisions matter, luck and risk play significant roles in our financial outcomes. Recognizing the influence of luck cultivates humility and guards against overconfidence. Additionally, understanding and managing risk is crucial for long-term financial stability. Diversification and avoiding large, irreversible mistakes can help mitigate the impact of unexpected events.
Compounding Â§
Building wealth is not about overnight success or chasing quick gains; itâ€™s about harnessing the power of compounding. By consistently saving and investing over time, even small amounts can grow exponentially. The key is to have patience and think long-term, allowing your money to work for you and accumulate wealth gradually. Most of Warren Buffet money are made after heâ€™s over 60. Disney almost went out of business before snow white. Success comes from executing consecutive horrible ideas. Ideas must acted upon.
Money is not just math Â§
Financial success is heavily influenced by our behaviors and mindset. Our emotions, biases, and tendencies impact our financial decisions more than we realize. Understanding our own behavioral patterns, such as our inclination to avoid losses or follow the crowd, can help us make better choices and avoid common financial pitfalls.
Financial Security Â§
Saving money and living below our means are essential for financial security. Regardless of income level, adopting a frugal mindset and being intentional about spending can create a solid financial foundation. Saving not only provides a safety net but also opens up opportunities for investment and wealth creation.
Resilience afd Adaptability Â§
Financial well-being requires resilience and adaptability. Being able to thrive in the face of adversity is crucial. Embracing uncertainty, learning from failures, and being flexible in our financial plans can help us navigate economic downturns and unexpected challenges. Building multiple income streams and having a diversified portfolio contribute to long-term resilience.
The Value of Contentment Â§
True wealth extends beyond monetary figures. It lies in finding contentment and satisfaction in non-financial aspects of life. Understanding our own values and aligning our financial goals accordingly can lead to a healthier and more balanced approach to money. Focusing on what truly brings us joy and fulfillment rather than constantly chasing more money can lead to a more satisfying life overall.
By embracing these key points, we can develop a more holistic and mindful approach to our finances, leading to greater financial well-being and long-term success.

Mind/Unveiling-Lasting-Happiness.title: Unveiling Lasting Happiness
Mind/Unveiling-Lasting-Happiness.content:
Discovering genuine and lasting happiness is a universal pursuit that goes beyond external achievements. Drawing inspiration from the principles of positive psychology, this article explores valuable insights on happiness.
1. Authentic Happiness Â§
True happiness lies in aligning our values, passions, and actions. By gaining self-awareness and living in harmony with our core values, we can unlock a sense of fulfillment and lasting joy.
2. The Power of Positivity Â§
Positive emotions play a vital role in our overall well-being. Embracing moments of joy, practicing gratitude, and actively seeking positive experiences can significantly impact our happiness.
3. Embracing Failure and Building Resilience Â§
Failure should be viewed as an opportunity for growth rather than a reason for fear. Learning from setbacks and cultivating resilience enables personal development and resilience in the face of challenges.
4. Nurturing Meaningful Relationships Â§
Meaningful connections and social support networks contribute significantly to our happiness. Cultivating relationships through active listening, empathy, and kindness fosters personal growth and a sense of belonging.
5. Mindful Living and Gratitude Â§
Practicing mindfulness allows us to fully experience the present moment, appreciating the beauty and joy in everyday life. Incorporating mindfulness exercises and gratitude practices enhances our overall well-being.
6. Balancing Work and Leisure Â§
Striking a healthy work-life balance is crucial for sustained happiness. Setting boundaries, prioritizing self-care, and engaging in activities that bring joy and relaxation contribute to our overall well-being.

Vim/Neovim-C++-debugger-setup-using-nvim.title: Neovim C++ debugger setup using nvim-dap and mason
Vim/Neovim-C++-debugger-setup-using-nvim.content:
Download codelldb binary Â§
To obtain codelldb binary, either install vscode extension lldb or download it using mason plugin.
The path will be differs based on the method used to downloaded. Use google to figure out path/to/codelldb.
Setting up adapter config Â§
The generic way codelldb work with nvim dap in a conceptuall level would be , have a debugging server running on a port like this mannually codelldb --port 1337 . and have nvim-dap connect to it.
But a better way is to launch the server automatically by the adapter and then connect to it. This was quite a headache until i came across a chinese dev forum.


                  
                  Tip
                  
                
Depending on your system, you may need to compile your app with debugger symbols
See c++ with debugging symbols.

 
 dap.adapters.codelldb = function(on_adapter)
   -- This asks the system for a free port
   local tcp = vim.loop.new_tcp()
   tcp:bind('127.0.0.1', 0)
   local port = tcp:getsockname().port
   tcp:shutdown()
   tcp:close()
 
   -- Start codelldb with the port
   local stdout = vim.loop.new_pipe(false)
   local stderr = vim.loop.new_pipe(false)
   local opts = {
     stdio = {nil, stdout, stderr},
     args = {'--port', tostring(port)},
   }
   local handle
   local pid_or_err
   handle, pid_or_err = vim.loop.spawn('/path/to/lldb', opts, function(code)
     stdout:close()
     stderr:close()
     handle:close()
     if code ~= 0 then
       print("codelldb exited with code", code)
     end
   end)
   if not handle then
     vim.notify("Error running codelldb: " .. tostring(pid_or_err), vim.log.levels.ERROR)
     stdout:close()
     stderr:close()
     return
   end
   vim.notify('codelldb started. pid=' .. pid_or_err)
   stderr:read_start(function(err, chunk)
     assert(not err, err)
     if chunk then
       vim.schedule(function()
         require("dap.repl").append(chunk)
       end)
     end
   end)
   local adapter = {
     type = 'server',
     host = '127.0.0.1',
     port = port
   }
   -- ğŸ’€
   -- Wait for codelldb to get ready and start listening before telling nvim-dap to connect
   -- If you get connect errors, try to increase 500 to a higher value, or check the stderr (Open the REPL)
   vim.defer_fn(function() on_adapter(adapter) end, 1000)
 end
 
 -- don't forget to compile/build with debug symbols, otherwise it won't work.
 dap.configurations.cpp = {
   {
     name = "runit",
     type = "codelldb",
     request = "launch",
 
     program = function()
       return vim.fn.input('', vim.fn.getcwd() , 'file')
     end,
 
     args = {"--log_level=all"},
     cwd = "${workspaceFolder}",
     stopOnEntry = false,
     terminal = 'integrated',
 
     pid = function()
             local handle = io.popen('pgrep hw$')
             local result = handle:read()
             handle:close()
             return result
     end
   },
 }
 
 dap.configurations.c = dap.configurations.cpp
 dap.configurations.h = dap.configurations.cpp
 dap.configurations.rust = dap.configurations.cpp
